October 10, 1999: Fiction
HARRY POTTER AND THE PRISONER OF AZKABAN, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $19.95.) A British boy's life at a school for witchcraft is
menaced when an infamous murderer escapes from prison.
HARRY POTTER AND THE CHAMBER OF SECRETS, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $17.95.) A British boy finds trouble when he returns to a
witchcraft school.
HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE, by J. K. Rowling.
(Levine/Scholastic, $16.95.) A British boy finds his fortune attending a school for
witchcraft.
HEARTS IN ATLANTIS, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $28.) Five long,
interconnected stories about an America haunted by the Vietnam War.
TARA ROAD, by Maeve Binchy. (Delacorte, $24.95.) Two women -- one from
Ireland, one from New England -- exchange houses for the summer.
THE ALIBI, by Sandra Brown. (Warner, $25.95.) Jealousy, intrigue and corruption
beset a Charleston lawyer during his pursuit of public office.
ASSASSINS, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $22.99.) The sixth
volume in a series about true believers who confront the Antichrist.
BLACK NOTICE, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $25.95.) Kay Scarpetta's
investigation of a ship's cargo gets her involved in an international conspiracy.
IN PURSUIT OF THE PROPER SINNER, by Elizabeth George. (Bantam, $25.95.)
Two English detectives investigate the murder of a man and a woman found near
an ancient circle of stones known as Nine Sisters Henge.
BIG TROUBLE, by Dave Barry. (Putnam, $23.95.) An outrageous chain of events
suddenly changes the lives of half a dozen people in Coconut Grove, Fla.
HARD TIME, by Sara Paretsky. (Delacorte, $24.95.) V. I. Warshawski copes with
mysteries involving a multimedia conglomerate and a prison for women.
HANNIBAL, by Thomas Harris. (Delacorte, $27.95.) Seven years after his escape,
the fiendish psychiatrist Hannibal Lecter is still at large.
DARK LADY, by Richard North Patterson. (Knopf, $25.95.) Stella Marz, a driven
county prosecutor, pursues criminals infesting a struggling Midwestern city.
FAMILY HONOR, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $22.95.) A policewoman turned
private detective is hired to find a missing teen-age girl.
APOLLYON, by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. (Tyndale, $19.97.) After the
October 10, 1999
Non-Fiction
'TIS, by Frank McCourt. (Scribner, $26.) An Irish immigrant gets used to life in
America: a memoir.
TUESDAYS WITH MORRIE, by Mitch Albom. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The author
recalls his old college mentor.
FAITH OF MY FATHERS, by John McCain with Mark Salter. (Random House,
$25.) A family memoir by the United States Senator and former P.O.W.
THE ART OF HAPPINESS, by the Dalai Lama and Howard C. Cutler. (Riverhead,
$22.95.) What Buddhism and common sense tell us about everyday problems.
THE GREATEST GENERATION, by Tom Brokaw. (Random House, $24.95.) The
lives of men and women who came of age during the Depression and World War
II.
ISAAC'S STORM, by Erik Larson. (Crown, $25.) An account of America's
deadliest hurricane.
THE SWORD AND THE SHIELD, by Christopher Andrew and Vasili Mitrokhin.
(Basic Books, $32.50.) How the K.G.B. operated during the cold war.
YESTERDAY, I CRIED, by Iyanla Vanzant. (Simon & Schuster, $22.) A counselor
describes how she turned painful experiences into feelings of hope.
THE MILLION DOLLAR MERMAID, by Esther Williams with Digby Diehl. (Simon &
Schuster, $26.) The autobiography of the film star of the 40's and 50's.
SHE SAID YES, by Misty Bernall. (Plough, $17.) The life of Cassie Bernall, a 17-
year-old junior who was killed at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo.
ETHICS FOR THE NEW MILLENNIUM, by the Dalai Lama. (Riverhead, $24.95.)
The ethical system Buddhism offers us for the present and the future.
THE HUNGRY OCEAN, by Linda Greenlaw. (Hyperion, $22.95.) An account of a
30-day swordfishing voyage.
A REPUBLIC, NOT AN EMPIRE, by Patrick J. Buchanan. (Regnery, $29.95.) A
history of our foreign policy, as perceived by the Presidential candidate.
BEEN THERE, DONE THAT, by Eddie Fisher with David Fisher. (Dunne/St.
Martin's, $24.95.) The autobiography of the popular singer.
REASON FOR HOPE, by Jane Goodall with Phillip Berman. (Warner, $26.95.)
The life, professional and spiritual, of the scientist who studied chimpanzees.
